issue.title: iterator reachability should not require a container

discussion.blockquote: An iterator j is called reachable from an iterator i if and only if there is a finite sequence of applications of the expression ++i that makes i == j. If j is reachable from i, they refer to the same container.
discussion.p: A good example would be stream iterators, which do not refer to a container. Typically, the end iterator from a range of stream iterators will compare equal for many such ranges. I suggest striking the second sentence.
discussion.blockquote: If j is reachable from i, and both i and j are dereferencable iterators, then they refer to the same range.
discussion.note: 2010 Pittsburgh: Moved to NAD Editorial. Rationale added below.

resolution.blockquote: An iterator j is called reachable from an iterator i if and only if there is a finite sequence of applications of the expression ++i that makes i == j. If j is reachable from i, they refer to the same container.
